title: open-culture-maybe-cake-10-museums-back-business
story: While we are still under the shadow of the virus, some things are beginning to come back, museums among them. The last few days has seen the reopening of both the National Museum of Scotland and Kelvingrove Museum. More will follow this coming week. And while access is controlled and there are limitations on where you can go, after months in lockdown the chance to visit your favourite museumis surely to be welcomed. Herersquos  you might like to visit soon. And remember to wear that mask when yoursquore indoors.National Museum of Scotland, EdinburghReopened on Wednesday on reduced hours , the National Museum of Scotland is once again the perfect retreat for those seeking refuge from the temperamental Edinburgh weather. Pre-booked timed entry, mandatory face coverings and one-way routes are all now in operation as the museum tries totonormal. Entrance will be by the west door on Chambers Street.The museumrsquos reopening will be phased in. The entrance hall and level one are now open to visitors, but rooms with a high number of interactive displays, including the Imagine and Explore galleries, remain closed for the moment.Inevitably, the museum has had to postpone a number of special exhibitions, but it is home to Scotlandrsquos Precious Seas, an exhibition that explores the nationrsquos erse sea le and the effect climate change is having on our maritime environment. Itrsquos part of the Year of Coasts and Waters.Visit nms.ac.uk for more details and to book entryKelvingrove Museum, GlasgowPre-booking is also required for Kelvingrove which has reopened its doors to the public from am to pm daily. Tickets will be available up to two weeks in advance, with a maximum of six visitors for each booking, all from the same family. Entry will be timed and will allow visitors a two-hour slot. A one-way system has been introduced, but most of the main gallery spaces are open. Masks are required and there will be no catering facilities. But the toilets are open. Entrance is by the carpark side.That only leaves one question. Whatrsquos the first thing yoursquore going to visit when you get back in  Are you there for the ancient Egyptian artefacts or for a catch-up with the work of Charles Rennie Mackintosh PS, the Riverside Museum is reopening on August . Put it in your diary.For more information and to book tickets, visit glasgowmuseumsNational Museum of Flight, East FortuneBooking in advance for timed entry is required for the National Museum of Flight in East Fortune. But at least you donrsquot need to self-quarantine when you get off the planes here. Some buildings are still closed unfortunately, but the Concorde Experience, the Parachute Store and the civil and military aviation hangars are all open, as well as the shop and cafe. One-way routes are in use.And, of course, the airfield itself is open, which means you can have a look inside the planes ndash therersquos a Vulcan, a Comet and a BAC - ndash on display. No passports required.Visit nms.ac.uk national-museum-of-flightfor details and bookings.The McManus art gallery and museum, DundeeNamed Scotlandrsquos best visitor attraction not long before lockdown, the McManus reopened on Thursday and remains one of the most reliable boltholes in Dundee .Now open daily from Tuesday to Saturday, am to pm, there is no booking necessary and exhibitions are free. The cafeacute has reopened with social distancing measures and the shop will only allow four customers at a time. Entry numbers to the museum will also be limited so you might have to queue.Joseph McKenzies photography at the McManusStill, it will be worth it. To celebrate its reopening, two new exhibitions have just opened. Time and Tide: The Transformation of the Tay looks at the importance of the river in the continuing story of the city, while A Love Letter to Dundee: Joseph McKenzie Photographs - celebrates McKenziersquos evocative and nostalgic black and white images of Dundee as it once was.Visit mcmanusfor more detailsVA Dundee, DundeeStill a few days to wait. The VA reopens its doors on Thursday. Pre-booked timed entry is now required, and social distancing measures and one-way systems have been introduced. But on the plus side the Tatha restaurant will reopen, as will the shop. As the ground floor cafeacute has closed, the Tatha will also offer cafe and takeaway options.And along with the regular galleries, the museum reopens with a new exhibition celebrating the work of Mary Quant, the first international retrospective of the revolutionary fashion designer. As far as we know wearing a mini skirt is not a requirement for entrance. Just as well. Some of us donrsquot have the legs for it.If yoursquore really keen, of course, you could double up with a trip to the Dovecot Studios in Edinburgh where the current exhibition Mid-Century Modern also focuses on Quant along with Terence Conran.Visit vam.ac.uk dundee to book ticketsThe Stirling Smith Art Gallery and Museum, StirlingAh, The Smith. There is no museum in Scotland Irsquove spent more time in over the years. Having just reopened, it will now be accessible from Thursday to Sunday, am to pm, with a one-way system in operation. No booking necessary.The Stirling Story exhibition continues to occupy its main exhibition space. Artist and collector Thomas Stuart Smith bequeathed his own work and collection to the museum and it forms the heart of The Man Who Could Paint Anything: The Legacy of Thomas Stuart Smith in gallery two, supplemented by donations by subsequent benefactors. The work of Anne Redpath, William McTaggart and William Gillies are all represented in the exhibition. Paul Eamesrsquo The Power of Flight, meanwhile, continues in gallery one until September .Even better news. The Smith Cafe has also reopened. The Sunday afternoons spent eating cake there hellipVisit smithartgalleryandmuseumfor more informationPerth Museum and Art Gallery, PerthPerths Discovering Egypt exhibitionAdvanced booking is required for ato Perth which has also introduced timed entries and a new one-way system.As well as all the usual attractions, Perth offers a number of exhibitions, including ICONS II: John Bellany and Conservation in Action. Discovering Ancient Egypt continues until October . And, of course, therersquos New Ways of Seeing: Scottish Art Schools, drawn from the museumrsquos permanent collection, which contains work by the likes of Joan Eardley, Anne Redpath, John Byrne and Sir Robin Philipson.The museumrsquos opening hours are Monday, Friday, Saturday and Sunday from am to .pm and pm to pm, and Thursday from .pm to .pm.Visit cultureperthandkinross.arttickets.org.uk to book tickets and for more informationScottish Fisheries Museum, AnstrutherWednesday is the day for the reopening of Anstrutherrsquos Scottish Fisheries Museum. Pre-booked timed entry and one-way routes through the museum will be in operation, with card payments only in the cafe and shop. Summer opening hours, which cover Wednesday to Sunday, am to pm, continue until the end of October.If you havenrsquot visited before, the museum has  boats and an extensive collectionof maritime artefats, photographs and paintings.It also must be one of the best situated museums for anyone wanting to top up with a fish supper afterwards.Visit scotfishmuseum.orgfor more informationRobert Burns Birthplace Museum, AllowayA substantial number of National Trust for Scotland properties have now reopened, including the Robert Burns Birthplace Museum in Alloway, which is open Thursday to Monday, from am to .pm. Entry offers access not only to the museum but to the cottage where the Bard was born. And as the cottage was rethatched and restored just before lockdown this may be the best time to see it.For more information visit nts.org.uk visit places robert-burns-birthplace-museum.Jim Clark Motorsport Museum, DunsThis Borders museum celebrates the le and achievements of one of Scotlandrsquos greatest sportsmen Jim Clark, twice Formula  world champion, who tragically died in  on the track at Hockenheim.The museum is home to the Lotus Cortina in which Clark won the  British Saloon Car Championship and a Lotus Type , one of the most iconic Formula  cars, driven by Clark in  Grands Prix between  and .For the moment, the museum is only open on Monday,Fridays and Saturdays between am and pmSundays from pm to pm. Numbers are limited, and advance booking is required.Visit for more details and to book jimclarktrust jim-clark-motorsport-museum

title: agenda-looking-power-culture-change-lives
story: THE Edinburgh International Culture Summit is a distinctive event in an exceptional city. Established in  and supported by a unique partnership between the British Council, the Edinburgh International Festival, the Scottish Parliament and the Scottish and UK Governments, it traditionally offers a biennial ministerial forum in which artists and cultural leaders come together with politicians and policy makers to discuss substantial, global issues of mutual interest during the largest annual celebration of the arts in the world ndash the Edinburgh Festivals.The Covid- pandemic prevents hosting the summit at the Scottish Parliament this year. However, the resulting move to a Special Edition entirely online gives us a dferent opportunity, a way to make the Culture Summit even more accessible and available to everyone, be they in business, policy making, politics, economy, the arts, or simply curious. Neither geography nor means is a barrier, all films are freely available on the Culture Summit site from today.In our present circumstances, the summitrsquos title ,The Transformational Power of Culture, seems particularly appropriate. In the midst of a devastating pandemic, governments and cultural leaders alike grapple with unprecedented challenges attempting to save lives and sustain careers. At such times, it is important that a summit such as this, should develop a narrative around the signicance of culture for other facets of human societies.The summitrsquos collaborators in  are actors, theatre directors, choreographers, novelists, librarians, painters, museum curators, musicians and singers. They are also architects, economists, educators, epidemiologists, historians, human rights advocates, medical and social scientists, philanthropists, philosophers and tech entrepreneurs.Very much in this spirit, and by way of an example, when considering an approach to one of our themes, Culture  Education, the summit has chosen to collaborate not only with some amazing young musicians who are part of youth orchestras in Los Angeles and Raploch here in Scotland, but quite deliberately with an economist, an epidemiologist, a neuroscientist and an educational entrepreneur cum philanthropist.This eclectic group of expertise has been enlisted to make the case for why culture matters, and why, from the perspective of health and well-being, economic prosperity, and most important of all, from an humanitarian point of view, it is so vital that culture and creativity together with the encouragement of empathy and emotional intelligence, should play a far greater role in our schools and classrooms.Many of the perspectives of our contributors remind me of the work of the pioneering educational psychologist Howard Gardner, who in , first proposed the concept of multiple intelligence not just linguistic and logical , but spatial, bodily-kinaesthetic, musical, interpersonal and intrapersonal forms of intelligence demonstrated by architects and sculptors, dancers and choreographers, athletes and gymnasts, business leaders, scientists and even politicians.Courtesy of Professor Gardner, the definitions of intelligence become vastly expanded. He argues persuasively that intelligence is not single-minded but multi-faceted. He describes the need for ldquomultiple intelligences to navigate the complex challenges of the world around us.The message for policy makers and politicians is urgent. Beyond the need for hope and inspiration in the lives of young people, there is an emerging body of knowledge from economists to neuroscientists which advocates for educational systems to place far greater emphasis on cultural learning opportunities and creativity from early childhood.Join us in embracing a world of creative potential, demonstrating the critical need for greater recognition of the role of culture as a catalyst to change our future. See www.culturesummitJonathan Mills is Director of the Edinburgh International Culture Summit

title: walk-govan-glories
story: In one of his biographies, Alex Ferguson expressed pride in his origins when he stated that ldquoto call Govan a district of Glasgow was an insult. Most Govanites would agree and the area is without doubt the one with the strongest sense of identity amongst the cityrsquos older working class districts.Many people would know that Govan was the former World Capital of Shipbuilding where at its height in the ldquoThree Yairds, men produced about a quarter of the worldrsquos tonnage of ships.They might also know that Govan was one of the cradles of the labour movement, with the emergence of trades unions, the co-operative organisations and the Labour Party, with a strong tradition of struggle from the Rent Strikes of World War One, through to the occupation of the shipyards in the early s with the UCS work-in. And would be aware that with the decline of shipbuilding in the last  years, Govan has fallen on hard times, its population reduced to less than , from the figure of , when the burgh was annexed by Glasgow in .But would they know that Govan is considerably older than Glasgow which annexed it  And that for centuries, as an ecclesiastical centre of the ancient Kingdom of Strathclyde, it was more important than the city  Would they know anything about Govanrsquos collection of early Christian incised stones, one of the finest in Scotland and indeed the UK .Possibly not and it might well surprise more than a few that Govan can claim to have the finest collection of A-listed buildings and public sculpture outside the city centre and west end of Glasgow, dating from the time of its economic prosperity and industrial greatness. Those yet ignorant ndash and even those in the know, since Govan is changing and developing after decades of stagnation ndash should hop on that clockwork orangeand disembark at Govan Cross subway station ndash and take the following walkabout round Central Govan as an introduction to hopefully further personal explorations.THE WALK. Around Govan Cross you see the beneficial effects of the Town Centre Action Plan, which at a cost of pound. million ndash a bankerrsquos bonus ndash made an improvement to the area, providing paving, seating, signage ndash and a restoration of the Aitken Fountain. This was an  memorial to Govanrsquos first Medical Officer of Health whose sanitary improvements massively reduced death rate in the mid-th century.As well as many other insignia the fountain sports the coat of arms of the burgh of Govan, established in , which shows ying icons but always a shiprsquos engineer and a shiprsquos carpenter. See how many such emblems you can spot on your ramble ndash and whether you can spot a single Glasgow one!There is much to here but the jewel is the refurbished former British Linen Bank by Salmon  Gillespie, an A-listed tenement from , with a delightful open-crown metal roof. Its sculptures are especially fine look at the one above the door showing two male angels driving a sailing boat by blowing their conches. Here you stand on Water Row, once a Roman road to a Clyde crossing, later the centre of the fishing and weaving community.. Moving west along the Govan Road, on your left is a statue of William Pearce, owner of the Fairfield yard and Govan MP in the s. Coming from the Chatham naval dockyard he brought war work and massive prosperity to Fairfieldrsquos, and to himself, dying worth a present day fortune of pound million. He stands beside Brechinrsquos Bar, a mock baronial building from over a century ago, which was originally Cardellrsquos Temperance Institute.Once when in there the punter next me at the bar turned unannounced and stated, ldquoSee that Noam Chomsky, we had him in here in the Year of Culture. I have never investigated the truth of this, nor of the claim of the regulars of Brechinrsquos that, at chucking out time, the Black Man, as they call the statue, takes a few steps.Opposite Brechinrsquos is located the Pearce Instutute or PI, known as the Heart of Govan. Lady Pearce gave the money for its foundation in memory of her husband and it opened in  as a cultural and social centre, with a theatre, library, billiard room and washing and cooking facilities for the majority who lacked adequate facilities. These were located in the Womenrsquos area, entered by a separate door. Times change, and females can enter the front door nowadays. The A-Listed PI was designed by Edinburgh architect Rowand Anderson in an eclectic style one half Dutch Renaissance, the other Scottish Vernacular. Atop the latter part sits a metal galleon made by the workers of Fairfields, who also contributed much free labour to helping build the. PI... Moving further west we reach the War Memorial to those killed in the First World War, behind which lies another of Govanrsquos glories, the Old Kirk . Space prohibits more than mentioning that this ndash also by Rowan Anderson ndash stands on a site that has probably been one of Christian worship for  years and a pagan one beforehand, and that it contains one of the finest collections of incised early Christian stones in Scotland, over  ndash crosses, grave slabs and the famous Govan Hogbacks as well as thereputed sargophacus of St Constantine. The connections with the Reformationand the Iona Community, add further fascination. .Between here and the next stop, Fairfields, there stands a iety of tenement buildings, some in good repair, some in less ndash and examples of the new tenements built in the last  years. The Lyceum, a former art-deco palace of a cinema is also passed and high up on it is an illustration of the original Lyceum Music Hall, destroyed in a fire. When it opened in , a packed audience heard a performance of Bizetrsquos Carmen. See Govan, see Kulcher.. On reaching ElderStreet on the right, the gates of the former Fairfield Yard, now BAE Systems, loom into view no longer do  men stream in and out of here twice a day the old tramlines which brought goods into the yards are still visible amongst the cobbles. A further walk along Govan Road brings you to the impressive front door of the former offices of the yard, now Fairfield Heritage, hosting a fine display on the history of shipbuilding housed in a building to match. The offices were designed by Keppie and Honeyman, the firm Macintosh later worked for, and though splendid inside, their finest feature is the doorway itself where amongst the usual icons of nymphs and Neptune, stand two le-size sandstone scultures of working men done by Pittendreich Macgillivray. This building is also A-Listed..Though achieving its maximum size under Pearce, the yard became a world leader under the previous owners, the Elders. Crossing the road gives a good view of the office building and also allows entrance to Elder Park, the only piece of ground in central Govan formerly not covered by tenements or industry. The park has a ied collection of sculptures relating to Govanrsquos history and a boating pond. Previously there was also a dairy farm and a small zoo!Just south of the park gates stands a statue of John Elder, leaning on the compound steam engine he invented, which gave Clyde shipbuilding a competitive edge. The statue was exectued by Boehm and is complemented by one of Isabella Elder herself further over in the park. Despite the importance of this place it was shockingly refused a Heritage Lottery grant some years ago ndash while many less worthy were not.Exiting the park is done from behind the library, with its splendid cast iron railings, and very fine frontage. The building was designed by another top Glasgow architect, J.J Burnet, and Govanites are proud of the fact they had a public library in  some years before Glasgow built their ious examples. Inside the building are busts of the Elders, and an interesting painting of pre-industrial Govan by Brotchie. This building is also A -Listed.. Moving back eastalong pedesrianised Langlands Road through an assortment of housing built to replace demolished tenements, brings us to Golspie Street, with its stunning ldquoAmsterdam-style new tenement, and then past the car park for the Govan Shopping Centre till we emerge back at Brechinrsquos and the Black Man with a very clear view of the PI. Back at Govan Cross, visit the excellent Cafe . Rest and reflect that you have only scraped the surface of central Govan, never mind Greater Govan...andyou leave unimpressed, there is no hope for you.Ian R Mitchell is the author of Walking through Glasgowrsquos Industrial Past

title: opinion-hugh-macdonald-never-met-fidelma-feel-like-many-part-life
story: This later caused her some embarrassment in her role as a waitress on a floating hotel. It was not plain sailing for me, either. Stilettos were not ideally suited for my afternoon duties as centre-half for Blantyre Celtic.This recollection of me as Bambi on horse anaesthetic is highly analogous to my faltering steps into Fidelmarsquos fiefdom. This bailiwick is guarded by an imperious Afghan hound, seems to have a lingering scent of jasmine and the soft echo of the pop of something sparkling.There is a straightforward choice when invading this space. Does one mumble something inane  Or does one acknowledge the absence of Fidelma and confront it head-on with the stark but sincere crudity of a Glasgow kiss  I have only reluctantly discarded the inanities option since it is, after all, my superpower. It has, though, been overwhelmed by the realisation there is something important to be said about absence, particularly in the case of one, specic columnist.There was a moment last week when I read the words of Fidelmarsquos son and was hit by an epiphany with the force of that aforementioned Glasgow kiss. His account of a draining trip to visit his mother in hospital contained what is called a vignette. .It was this: the weary traveller confronts ailing mum. He asks a question. There is no immediate answer. Has he not been recognised "Was it my face mask  Was she so sick that she did not recognise mehellip  It felt like minutes had passed before she mumbled weakly through her mask, lsquoYou could have at least worn a shirt and maybe some white shorts. Itrsquos such a waste to see you dress badly like the French.rsquo"Regressing to my superpower of uttering banalities, I told myself that many of her readers would similarly be unacquainted with Fidelma in the narrow terms of physical meetings, private conversations.This points to the brilliance of a certain kind of newspaper column. There are many columnists who make extraordinary claims about their work. They can be the Voice of Anything From Reason To Football to Interpretation of Sanskrit Scrolls.One famous financial columnist was once told by a sub-editor that his latest offering was unintelligible. "I am writing for three people in England," the columnist replied. "And you are not one of them." The three comprised the Chancellor of the Exchequer, the governor of the Bank of England and the permanent under-secretary to the Treasury, apparently. This story sounds so authentic to an old hack that it might almost be true.It is certainly irrefutable that many columns totter uneasily on the twin pillars of certainty and unbridled preaching, both based on a solid foundation of ego.Now, Fidelma may be read by the Chancellor of the Exchequer or, I suspect, by the First Minister. But she is not writing for him or her. She is writing for herself. She takes her le with its routine humiliations, its senseless pain and its occasional, and overwhelming joy and presents it to us with an eloquence that is only superseded by her bravery. She tells us every Saturday how she is feeling as a dog sulks, bones complain and her house gently falls down around her.There is anger, contentment, bitterness, resignation, humour, sadness, happiness and even consolation in all of this. The dog finally comes in. The pain usually subsides. And the house  Well, who cares  Itrsquos a house, it has a fridge, it hosts a glass and there is a tincture of something pleasantly numbing in its deepest interior.We ndash or certainly I ndash read all this with a sense of bright satisfaction that sometimes belies the darkness of some of the content. This is because I have been privileged to have been invited into a le. We can share an unflinching gaze at the reality of ageing. As that great Scottish philosopher, Billy Connolly, once intoned: lsquoOld age is not for softies.rsquoThis toughness in Fidelma is enhanced at both her realisation of this truth and her defiance in the face of it. Her superpower, though, is somewhat miraculous. Think of this. A woman lies across the water, fighting against illness. Thousands of people who have never met her, from Bargeddie to Bearsden, from Callander to Cumnock and Carrbridge, wish her well.This offers welcome proof of the capacity for compassion, of the boundless ability we have to reach out to others. We care about a person we have never met. This is a tribute to Fidelmarsquos writing. But it is more than that. Most wondrously, it is a recognition of the trials and triumphs of a shared humanity articulated by a single voice.Thatrsquos some trick, Fidelma. Can you do it again, please  And soon.

title: big-fan-online-shopping-not-without-peril
story: I suppose it comes down to whether you view shopping as a pleasurable, leisure activity or a tedious, begrudged chore when you could be curled up in an armchair with a good book.Thats not to say I dont feel melancholy to see high streets across Scotland become pitul shadows of the once-bustling thoroughfares. It would be nice to get the hearts of our towns and cities beating again, although Im unconvinced rows of shops is the answer .The big out-of-town retail parks arent something Im fond of either. A couple of times a year, Ill do "a day at the shops" ndash as others are wont to call it ndash which is usually sufficient to dissuade me of the notion for another six months or so.:Susan Swarbrick: Need a little sorbet for the soul  Step this way ...That said, shopping online is not without peril. Heres some of my less-wise purchases from the world wide web in recent months.A camping hammockThe hammock itself is robust and well-made. When I purchased it, I had visions of lying in it of a Sunday afternoon enjoying a good book. What I didnt consider was that the swaying motion is not conducive to a relaxing time for someone with a predisposition to severe motion sickness.Even in the gentlest of breezes, it feels like Im aboard a pitching and rolling ship during a Force  storm. If I had tried the hammock in a shop first, I would have realised this. Still, the dog seems to like it and often hops in for a nap.Cheap jogging bottomsBought on a whim thinking they would be good for lounging about the house and pottering in the garden . I despise them. Wearing these joggers is akin to being a walking black hole, drawing in anything and everything in your path.They hold a static charge that packs a punch and attract clumps of dog hair like no other item of clothing I have known. I stepped outside the other day and within seconds my breeks had a layer of street debris, dandelion seeds, several bird feathers and an empty Wotsits bag clinging to them.A potato grow bagThe photograph on the website showed a grow bag containing five or six potato plants. "Jolly good", I thought and ordered one. What arrived wouldnt look out of place on Lilliput Lane. It is tiny.:Susan Swarbrick: The worlds most spirit-crushing job Fitting two plants in was a tight squeeze and when I had a feel around beneath the compost to check on the growth of the potatoes, such is their cramped quarters that months later they are still the size of rabbit pellets. We live and learn.Our columns are a  for writers to express their opinions. They do not necessarily represent the views of The Herald

title: letters-time-highlight-toll-roads
story: Why do we not give such recognition to the deaths that occur on Scotlands roads  Many more of us, indeed, just about all of us, travel on our roads and, in an average week, three people are killed on Scotlands roads. Yet each incident incurs merely the briefest of mentions. We rarely,ever, hear of any investigation and steps being taken to prevent similar incidents in the future. Families are devastated every week by these deaths, many of which could be avoidedthe same rigour was applied to our road traffic system as is applied to our railways. Train drivers are tested regularly and the infrastructure and trains are examined frequently to set standards. Road drivers are tested once, with no subsequent health checks and no updates issued to them on changes in driving standards or procedures.What is the cost of a human le  It obviously depends on where and how you die. We appear to live in a society where death on the roads is accepted as a price to be paid for the freedom to roam freely on our roads.Patricia Fort, Glasgow G.PASSING FOR PRIVILEGEIF there is one thing that the current crisis in educational achievement has demonstrated, it must surely be that government and establishment interference in examination attainment is something that has been going on for generations. The current row is not so much linked to the consequences of the virus in extremis but to the simple fact of having being found out. Private and privileged schools are traditionally upgraded and the schools from poorer and deprived areas routinely downgraded to balance and control exam inflation.If you ever wondered why Oxbridge is rammed with students from Eton and Harrow, wonder no more.DH Telford, Fairlie.ALEXANDER Thomrsquos Agenda articledoes justice to the loneliness of the long-distance running of PhD students. Irsquom sure he will not be reduced to the despair of one North American student I heard about, who took an axe to his supervisor eventually. The fact that the student could find the supervisor,only to take an axe to them, would be a cause for celebration in some cases. Yet supervisors themselves will often think, and probably say, ldquoIf yoursquore not writing this thesis, nobody  is.Good luck to the future Dr Thom in keeping his head down, getting it finished, and gaining his Glasgow gown with the crimson facings.Gilbert MacKay, Newton Mearns.CROSSING THE TEAI THINKIan Thomsonwants to comment on US politics he should make sure of his facts. Sarah Palin was an arch Republican, not a Democrat, and Geraldine Ferrarro was a Democrat, not a Republican. I cannot understand how he could confuse a Tea Party founder Republican with the Democrat party.Rob Smith, Stirling.ODE TO THE HERALD I BELIEVE I may be able to assuage Gerry Burkes unhappiness about the absence of a daily poem from Lesley Duncan . I suggest this:Take two or three paragraphs at random from almost any section of The Herald chop them into lines of unequaldont bother with trles like capital letters, rhyme, or metre add an enigmatic title ndash et voila! You have a piece of modern poetry.Donald R Buchanan, Bearsden.

title: issue-day-ub40-reunion-no-way
story: UB The reggae pop band, which formed in Birmingham in , were one of the biggest acts of the s and s, finding global success with hit songs such as rsquos Red, Red Wine and rsquos duet with Chrissie Hynde, I Got You Babe, as well as rsquos I Canrsquot Help Falling in Love With You. They have sold more than  million records worldwide.They split The eight-strong line-up remained largely the same from the outset for nearly  years, including Ali Campbell on vocals, his brother Robin on guitar and friend Mickey Virtue on keyboards, as well as percussionist and rapper, Astro, but then in January , Ali left the band.Why did he leave He said at the time that management dficulties had become "intolerable", adding: "I have an ongoing investigation into the handling of my business affairs in relation to UB. Suffice to say, I felt I had no other option but to resign from my band." He added that UB were "my family for the last  years and will always be my brothers.But even then A band spokesman disputed this take, saying: "Alis statement is incorrect with respect to the situation of management. Since then, the brothers have been engaged in a war of words and legal disputes.A new UB was formed Ali now performs under the name UB featuring Ali Campbell and Astro. But UB still perform under the original name, with Ali and Robinrsquos brother, Duncan, as the lead vocalist. Fans were left stunned - and torn between the groups.A reunion It seems dead in the water after Ali, now , was interviewed on Good Morning Britain, in the wake of his brother, Duncan, , suffering a stroke days earlier. Askedissues could be resolved, he said: ldquoI was kind of betrayed by themhellipIrsquom just happy to carry on promoting reggae and our version of UB.And when asked by NMEthe band could bury the hatchethellip He said: ldquoNo, thatrsquoll never happen. Theyrsquore failing miserably and wersquore flying high, so I wouldnrsquot dream of going back to them. There will never be a reunion.Oasis Itrsquos almost too obvious to mention, but of course, Oasis siblings, Noel and Liam Gallagher split in , with Noel saying: ldquoPeople will write and say what they like, but I simply could not go on working with Liam a day longer.Therersquos some hope The Kinks brothers, Ray and Dave Davies, have had a notoriously volatile relationship since the band formed in the early s, with Dave saying at one point: ldquoYoursquove heard of vampires  Well, Ray sucks me dry of ideas, emotions and creativity. Hersquos a control freak. But last September, it emerged they had moved next door to each other in London.

title: agenda-snug-elite-bbc-needs-get-act-together-apologise
story: WHAT was that jury thinking about  Did the  honest and true citizens not know that Kirsty Wark was doing a documentary in conjunction with her husbandrsquos production company Two Rivers Were they not informed that this documentary was to be a blockbuster hurrah for the Me Too Movement as Scotlandrsquos former First Minister Alex Salmond was led away in shame How dare they impede this latter-day Madame Defarge as she knitted together a TV documentary that was based on the assumption by her and the other Les Tricoteuses that the jury woulda guilty verdict The BBCrsquos mission statement promises ldquoto act in the public interesthellip impartial, high-quality and distinctive output and services which inform, educate and entertain.Impressive aspirations. It is a pity it seems to have forgotten these goals when producing its BBC documentary The Trial of Alex Salmond.Many years ago, when I edited Scotlandrsquos biggest-selling newspaper Ms Wark publicly chastised me for using a headline, ldquofilly folly, when a leading politician was caught in a tryst with the lady who ran a local riding stable. It was too tabloidy for Ms Warkrsquos delicate taste. Well for me the BBCrsquos The Trial of Alex Salmond was far too tabloidy to be taken seriously.I have no doubt the BBC hierarchy was aware of the links between Ms Wark, her husband, Alan Clements, and the programmersquos production company Two Rivers.All parties are too professional and too long in the media game to have it otherwise. They would not allow criticism that this relationship was too cosy and edging towards nepotistic. But who in the BBC hierarchy allowed this programme to be aired when the very foundations of the concept had been critically damaged when the Salmond jury ed its not guilty, and on one charge not-proven, verdicts Filly folly indeed.Did the BBC mandarins who commissioned the programme know that Ms Wark and the former First Minister had history  The Commission had to issue an apology following a  Newsnight encounter.I certainly think another apology would be in order. This wasnrsquot a balanced programme, this was no more than an hour-long assassination of Alex Salmond. Perhaps The Re-Trial of Alex Salmond by TV would have been a better title.In a matter of days the new Director-General of the BBC Tim Davie will be ushered into his central London office and later in the autumn Steve Carson will settle in to his Clydeside office as the new director of BBC Scotland. We wish them luckhellip and they are going to need it.The BBC will be  years old in , and more and more it looks its age. Tired, sluggish, bloated. But what challenges face this warm, snug, elite old club There is the small matter of the TV licence system which is under review. The growing call to defund the BBC started as a whisper and can now be heard loud and clear throughout the UKMr Davie will have to ask himself: is his BBC equipped to compete in a media landscape ravished by economic cutbacks that are inevitable post-Covid If these issues and a myriad of others are not addressed ASAP therersquos a fair chance there wonrsquot be enough people around to blow-out the candles on the centenary birthday cake.Now, that would be a documentary.Jim Cassidy is a journalist and communications specialist

title: herald-diary-boris-plays-wally
story: SOME people stay young at heart all their lives. Or to put it another way, they never grow up. Which brings us, inevitably, to Britains glorious leader. Boris Johnson, crafty scamp that he is, has been playing a game of hide-and-seek with his countrymen. While the public sought leadership he scurried to a remote Scottish cottage, perhaps hoping to avoid discovery for the duration of his premiership. Alas, the sighting of a ridiculous bobble-hat brought the press to his door.Perhaps we shouldnrsquot be too harsh about Boris. As the following tales from our vaults prove, we all have periods when our inner child goes outerhellip then out of control. For instance, an elderly lady once despondently informed us her nephew had been involved in a lsquofricasseersquo down the pub.Dark discoveryTHE Diary has always had a soft spot for those goths who lurk on street corners, Dracula-like. Or maybe that should be Dracula-lite. One such teenage boy, dressed in black with a stud in his nose, once casually explained: ldquoI donrsquot really like to wear this gear, but it keeps my parents from dragging me everywhere with them.Stepping outA GLASGOW doctor once claimed he told a patient recovering from heart surgery that he would be able to resume a normal sex le as soon as he could climb two flights of stairs without being out of breath. His patient frowned, then replied: ldquoWhatI look for a wummin who lives on the ground floor Duncan the donut FORMER Rangers star Duncan Ferguson was a towering presence on the football pitch. Uncharitable iniduals have claimed that in the intellectual stakes he has never quite loomed over his fellow men in the same manner.A Diary contact once swore the following tale about Big Duncrsquo was true. Apparently he telephoned the company that put a new security system in his house to say he didnrsquot know the code for switching on the alarm. The woman on the other end began to explain: ldquoJust use the standard code of --- until you decide on your own code... She was interrupted by Duncan, who said: ldquoHang on while I get a pen.Green about greensSCHEMES to encourage young people to eat more fruit and veg havenrsquot succeeded particularly well in certain parts of Glasgow. A reader was once in a Toryglen Asda when the checkout girl came across an item she failed to recognise. In order to price it, she asked our chap what it was.ldquoBroccoli, he patiently explained.Man troubleA CONVERSATION once overheard in a Glasgow wine bar: ldquoAnd after breaking off the engagement he had the cheek to want his ring back, says a disgruntled gal.ldquoWhat did you tell him  asks her pal.ldquoWell, I just said: lsquoIn that case I want my virginity back.rsquoDrippy hippyWE end with a childish joke a reader once told us: Why didnrsquot the leguard save the hippy  He was too far out, man.

title: goodbye-pal-stuart-christie-scotlands-famous-anarchist-ron-mckay
story: Stuartrsquos le may have been plastered with headlines, Britainrsquos most famous anarchist was the usual description, but the small print of it was what was important, his loyalty, not just to what he believed in but to his friends and family, his remarkable intelligence, his self-deprecating, droll and spiky humour. Physically he was also tall and handsome, totally imperturbable, probably from having faced the worst. He was someone whose best qualities most of us would strive to emulate, and fail. Branwen described him as her rock. He was.I saw him last in February in Glasgow, we went for a drink or two in the Doublet on the edge of his native Partick, then to the Shish Mahal for a curry, where we planned the trip we would never take. The original one, viewed from now, had its moments of high farce.He had told his family that he was going grape-picking in France, instead he was travelling to Paris on a single ticket and a handful of change to pick up explosives to deliver to comrades in Madrid who were planning to blow up Franco and his cabinet on a dais at Real Madridrsquos Bernabeacuteu stadium. The only French he knew was zut alors, which amused his anarchist hosts, and his Spanish was non-existent. He was to wear a bandage on his hand so his contact could recognise him and he had to be taught a phrase ndash me duele la manondash as a coded response.He set out to the south with the plastic explosive taped to his body, hitchhiking and wearing a kilt so that hersquod get lts, which led to reports in the Argentine press that a Scottish transvestite had tried to kill the Caudillo. His last lt in France broke down just short of the Spanish border and Stuart had to push the car across, sweating and hoping the plastic would hold firm, under the gaze of the Guardia Civil in their shiny, patent, three-cornered hats.The mission had been infiltrated by an informer and when Stuart handed over the package to Fernando Carballo Blanco, a carpenter who was constructing the dais and would place the charges, they were swooped on. It was August , A Hard Dayrsquos Night was top of the hit parade and Alec Douglas-Home was Prime Minster, doing economics with matches. The two were convicted on September  in a brief trial before a military tribunal, Blanco given  years.It was undoubtedly international pressure and publicity that deterred the lsquocourtrsquo from passing the customary death sentence for lsquoterrorismrsquo, which was then carried out by garrotte, the medieval process of neck-breaking in a slow mechanical strangulation by a metal collar and a bolt through the neck.Stuart was mildly roughed-up by Francorsquos secret police but he was forced to watch his co-conspirator brutally tortured. Blancorsquos father had been shot and murdered by Francorsquos forces for being a trade unionist, driving his mother mad with grief and ending in an asylum. Although Stuart was released after just less than four years after an appeal by his mother, Blanco served  years. When I was contacted by his niece last week she denied that he had been a hero. ldquoHe just wanted to free the Spanish people, she said.Franco was an unapologetic fascist and dictator who led the overthrow of the Republican government, precipitating the civil war, with the blood of many thousands, and not just combatants, on his hands. As he put it: ldquoOur regime is based on bayonets and blood, not on hypocritical elections.Stuartrsquos memory of the show trial, conducted in Spanish of course which he could not then understand, was of  army officers, heavy with medals, swords on the table in front of them, comprising what passed for a jury in a large, sticky, vaulted room. He said he felt he had been transported into the final act of some grand opera. ldquoI was  years and six weeks old, a boy from working-class Glasgow and Irsquod never been to the opera, he remembered.He learned Spanish in the Carabanchel jail and sat A-levelsand was sent money regularly from Britain but also from Spanish anarchists. The only English names they seemed to know were John, Paul, George and Ringo, so the donations turned up in these names and the authorities thought he was being funded by the Beatles.He was released in , got work as a gas fitter as Britain was converting to North Sea gas and inadvertently almost blew up a large part of Essex when he was unable to stop a massive gas leak.In , after having been arrested and spending  months in jail on remand, Stuart was acquitted of being a member of the Angry Brigade, which had carried out a series of casualty-less explosions against Edward Heathrsquos government. He claimed, and the jury believed him, that the police had planted two detonators in his car. One of the four of the convicted Stoke Newington Eight, John Barker, said later about his own experience, ldquoThe police fitted-up a guilty man.Two years later Stuart and I holidayed in a remote cottage up a narrow, pebbled track outside Oban, where we walked, talked and sank a few malts in the evening round a roaring fire. At the same time a Francoist banker had been kidnapped by an anarchist group and a ransom paid. When Stuart ed to London he was warned by a friendly Special Branch officer that he wasnrsquot safe and should get out of town, which he did with his we Brenda, first to Yorkshire and then the remote Orkney island of Sanday, to a house called Over the Water.Then, the island might have been some prototype of an anarchist society, in that it was peacefully,bibulously, self-governing, with only an occasional police presence coming in by ferry from the mainland, the officersrsquo travel well telegraphed. Irsquom not sure anyone there bothered with car insurance. On one occasion a man was arrested for alleged drunk driving, the local doctor refused to test him and by the time the coppers had somehow managed to hire a boat and take him to the main island he was sober.I visited him and Brenda often, and many an evening was spent in the Kettletoft Hotel bar, often with instruments and a sing-song going, irregardless of conventional closing time, until the last patron exited. On one occasion two bold officers turned up and insisted that the bar was cleared at pm, to the considerable ire and disgruntlement of those of us who considered the evening was just beginning.There was a party to go to and Stuart and some others light-heartedly berated the two policemen now sitting in a car outside with the windows down. While he and they kept the officers occupied someone crept round the back of the car and let the tyres down.We sped off waving.Stuart and Brenda spent seven years on Sanday, Branwen was born there, and from the island he launched his publishing house the Cienfuegos Press , a major publisher of anarchist literature, and a radical newspaper, the Free-Winged Eagle. The local minister of course denounced him as the ldquoanti-Christ.Stuart Christie was born in Partick to a hairdresser and a hard-drinking trawlerman, Albert. He was named Stuart after Bonnie Prince Charlie, ldquothe only man in history to be called after three separate sheepdogs, according to fellow Partiquois Billy Connolly. When he was six his parents went to friends for a drink, his dad was given a glass of sherry which he looked at in disgust, poured down the sink and walked out the door without saying a word. ldquoThe joke was that he had gone for a packet of fags, but thatrsquos the last time we saw him until he turned up  years later, Christie recalls.By then Stuart had a half-sister, Olivia. But the formative influence on him had been his granny Agnes McCulloch Davis, with whom he did most of his growing up on Arran and in Glasgow. He described her as the moral barometer in his le, ldquoand she provided the star I followed. She kept me on the straight and narrow. Well, with a few well-publicised detours!His partial autobiography, a compilation of three self-published volumes, was appropriately called Granny Made Me An Anarchist, in which many of the truths are told. Itrsquos a rollicking account peppered with cultural and political reference points, from the Jeely Piece Song, to Leslie Howard, Buntildeuel and Just William. Itrsquos also extremely funny.He also wrote a trilogy of novels iexclPistoleros! The Chronicles of Farquar McHarg, about a fictional Scottish anarchist born in  who became involved in the Spanish civil war, which weaves in actual happenings and some of the principal villains of the time. Stuart also managed to pack in a degree in history and politics along the way.Brenda Christie died in June last year, nursed by her husband and earlier this year Stuart moved to Colchester to be near daughter Branwen and her girls, his granddaughters Merri and Mo, for too short a time. He had previously fought cancer, this time it was lung cancer which spread to the bone. His suffering was mercully short.Irsquove been with him when hersquos been introduced to people and occasionally the response would be, ldquoNot that Stuart Christie ! To which hersquod always answer, ldquoThe West of Scotland ballroom dancing champion  Some poor unfortunate had the same name.For the record he was a terrible dancer.

title: herald-view-recession-now
story: Of course, everyone understands why we are here. This is not a normal year: the UK was faced with tackling coronavirus and saving lives and it meant effectively shutting down large parts of the economy and paying almost  million people not to go to work, at a cost of poundbillion so far. But from August, employers have had to start contributing towards the cost of furlough and the scheme is expected to end in October. The question is: what then The Chancellor Rishi Sunak says there is no possibility of an extension because of the economic cost and he points out that most other countries are making similar moves to phase out their schemes. But one country that isnrsquot is Germany. The government there is expected to announce next week that it will extend Kurzarbeit, which was the model for furlough, from  months to two years and the reason the finance minister Olaf Scholz gave was clear. ldquoThe corona crisis wonrsquot suddenly disappear in the next few weeks, he said.The German finance ministerrsquos logic is hard to refute. The economic damage done by coronavirus will not stop suddenly in October just because the Chancellor has stopped the furlough scheme ndash indeed, the end of furlough will deepen the trouble for many employers and itrsquos likely the real nature and scale of the economic crisis will only become obvious then. There are some businesses that would be perfectly viable in normal circumstances that may go underfurlough is abruptly ended.The picture also looks grim for particular sectors that continue to be badly hit. Some remain completely shut down ndash the countryrsquos theatres and concert venues for example. Others, such as pubs and restaurants, are being forced to operate way below their normal capacity, thereby hitting profits. For these sectors, the furlough scheme will continue to be essential way beyond October and the UK Government should think again about an extension.Naturally, the cost of such an extension is a concern, but it must be weighed against the possible costs of not extending, the biggest of which could be mass unemployment the cost of borrowing has also never been so low ndashever there was a time to borrow for the sake of the economy, this is it. It might also be possible to limit the cost of extending the furlough scheme by targeting it at the areas that need it most.The uncertain effect of withdrawing furlough, and the fact that it will not apply equally across the economy or dferent parts of the UK, also points to a particular dficulty for the Scottish Government. Since the beginning of the pandemic, the Scottish, Welsh and Northern Irish governments have taken slightly dferent decisions at dferent times and yet the devolution settlement means the Scottish Government could not extend furlough in Scotland because it does not have the borrowing powers to fund it. The First Minister has repeatedly complained about this and it is time the UK Government listened.There are other ideas the UK Government should consider as we hopefully move from crisis into containment into recovery. Scrapping or freezing employersrsquo national insurance payments for example. A holiday on business rates would also help the countryrsquos town centres to begin the fight-back. All of it will cost ndash and all of it will have to be paid back in some way in due course ndash but the alternative is a clf-edge in October that will deepen the economic crisis rather than ease it. The scale of the mountain we have to climb is clear and the Scottish and UK governments will have to take unprecedented action for a long time to come yet to ensure we get over it.

title: workers-sec-lose-jobs-furlough-scheme-winds
story: In an e-mail sent to staff and shared with the The Herald, Levy Restaurants - the company which employs hospitality staff at the venue- toldworkers their last furlough payment would be made on September .Valentina Severa Clavell, a worker at Finnieston-basedvenuesaid they had received "barely any communication and support".:Scottish Government told to stop savage job cuts at Donald Trumps Turnberry resortWorkers were told that due to the fact live events were not able to continue because ofongoing restrictions, the company would not continue their employment.A Unite hospitality spokesman confirmed the news: "The way in which Levy Restaurants have treated their staff at Scottish Events Campus is nothing short of disgraceful.There is an alternative to mass redundancy available till at least October  in the Job Retention Scheme. Instead Levy are looking to terminate all core and casual staffin the next few weeks because fromSeptemberthey will be expected to contribute a measly % towards their wages."Casual workers arent even going to be consulted. They have simply sent them a letter informing them that they will be removed from the furlough scheme in  weeks."We had thought given Glasgow City Councils role as a % shareholder in the Campus, that Levywould seek to treat its workforce fairly and reasonablybut evidently not."The affected staff do not work for the SEC but rather Levy Restaurants. It is understood that while the council owns % of shares in the SEC, it does not run the company or control the board.Green MSP for Glasgow Patrick Harvie has called on the Scottish government to intervene to save jobs.He said: ldquoJob losses on this scale are absolutely devastating for the city as well as for the iniduals involved. Glasgow city council own the SEC so itrsquos vital that it and the Scottish Government explore every avenue available to prevent these jobs going. Itrsquos been clear for some time though that ending the furlough scheme on a clf edge would lead to huge numbers of job losses. The Chancellor must now put peoplersquos livelihoods first and commit to extending the furlough scheme into .The e-mail, which wassent to staff "in batches", claimedMs Severa Clavell, reads: "We took the decision to furlough you and the majority of Levy people because we hoped that events wouldin the short term.:In pictures: Boris Johnson holidaying in Scotland"It has become increasingly clear that concerns, sporting and other major events will onlyin a behind closed doors fashion at this stage."The prospects of fully attended events is many months away and may onlyin ."Employees were told they would no longer be furloughed from September  and that they would receive their last payment the week after.The Scottish Events Campus - previously called the SECC - is one of Scotlands busiest venues. The campus is home to the SSE Hydro and the Armadillo and has played host to a number of gigs and events since its opening in . The Hydro was opened in .A council spokesman said: "The council is obviously very concerned by the loss of any jobs as a result of the ongoing pandemic ndash but we donrsquot have any direct involvement with Levy.Levy Restaurants have been approached for comment.The Scottish government has been approached for comment.

title: hey-siri-voice-assistants-female-new-research-aims-find
story: On our phone, on our smart speakers or tablets, AI-powered voice assistants tend to be young, female voices, subservient and designed to soak up even the most aggressive behaviour while giving us what we want.Now a major research programme is set to get underway involving three Scottish universities, aimed at probing the potential risks and harmful gender biases posed by female voice assistants and chatbots.The study will look into whether the proleration of obedient female voices found across a range of electronic devices ndash such as Applersquos Siri and Amazonrsquos Alexa ndash and which are increasingly appearing on company websites, might eventually spark changes in how we interact in the real world.As well as looking at their potential influences on human behaviour, the study will consider how AI characters may be developed in the future and whether they even need to be lsquohumanrsquo sounding at all.The study is in response to a UNESCO report last year which warned that the articial voice assistants may conjure up an image of women as being subservient, obliging, and eager to please.Entitled lsquoIrsquod Blush If I Couldrsquo ndash the standard response Applersquos Siri originally gave when called a lsquobitchrsquo - the report highlighted the way the female voices deflected insulting comments and aggression with feeble or apologetic responses, some of them even bordering on being flirtatious.The concern was that the voices were sending a signal that women are ldquodocile helpers who respond to blunt voice commands such as ldquoOK or ldquohey and set to honour commands regardless of the tone.The report pointed out that the voices tended to be created by teams of male engineers with little ersity present and concluded by urging developers to consider gender neutral voice assistants and programmes which discourage gender-based abuse.The new study, involving researchers at Heriot-Watt, Strathclyde and Edinburgh universities, will explore how users mentally visualise the AI voicesrsquo characters and whether their gender can have positive or negative impacts.An initial element of the research will be conducted on Thursdayduring an online workshop, in which members of the public will be asked to listen to AI voices and draw their vision of how they might look.The workshop, which is part of the Royal Society of Edinburghrsquos summer Curious programme of science talks, will also consider Beep, the BBCrsquos voice assistant which is currently in development. Unlike many AI voices, it has been given a gender-neutral, north east of England accent.Verena Rieser, Professor in Computer Science at Heriot-Watt University, where researchers will look into methods employed to build conversational agents, said: ldquoWhen people think of Amazonrsquos Alexa, they probably imagine a woman, perhaps in some sort of secretarial position.ldquoWe are askingthey have to be female and so human-like ldquoThen there is the behaviour of these systems when they are asked something thatrsquos not appropriate.ldquoThe danger is that when people interact with these systems they may reinforce gender stereotypes: you are talking to a woman, insulting her and yet she is not even pushing back.The three-year study will involve research on the psychological impacts of the AI voices to be carried out by researchers at Strathclyde University and which will analyse what messages the female AI voices convey and how they might influence behaviour.While a digital education element will also be carried out by researchers at Edinburgh University, which will look at how AI systems are constructed.ldquoWe are interested in finding out why these systems are the way they are andit stems from the fact that the people who build them are not a very erse workforce, added Prof. Rieser.Amazon has previously said test users responded most strongly to a female voice for its Alexa assistant. Microsoft has also said it found a female voice best embodied the qualities expected of a digital assistant ndash helpful, supportive and trustworthy.Meanwhile Google has said that it planned to use a male voice for its assistant, but the technology responded better to a higher pitched female format. Last year it introduced  dferent voices in an effort to introduce more ersity.However, itrsquos possible that the AI voice of the future could be less obliging young secretary and a little more CP.Prof. Rieser added: ldquoThe argument in the original UNESCO report says we dont have to make them human voices, and they could be much more clearly robotic.ldquoBut then,you make them too robotic, does that make them creepy Designing a Feminist Alexa ndash An Exercise in Empathic Design on Thursday, August , is part of the RSE Curious summer programme.

title: back-business-aberfoyle
story: Aberfoyle was celebrating a revival in its fortunes with a host of fledgling businesses opening up, For Sale signs taken down from the main thoroughfare, and a booming number of visitors ing to the once forgotten former tourist mecca.A year later, little could those new businesses have imagined the turbulence they were about to face. With Covid- challenging even the most well--established companies, how could the new kids on the block cope ldquoThe roof fell in, is how Bob Taylor describes it. He and his we had just launched Maggiersquos Aberfoyle Kitchen in Main Street in June  and thought the toughest challenge for them would be the businesses surviving its first winter when the leblood tourist trade dries up in the Stirlingshire village.ldquoEverything obviously fell apart in March and we struggled in the early days, he said. ldquoWe were allowed to stay open because we are a food shop but we decided to close as it was quite scary here. People were still coming ndash it was like a Bank Holiday weekend on some days. People were still travelling.In the early days of lockdown businesses relied on local support wherever they could. ldquoIn April, we opened for two days a week ndash Friday and Saturday, Mr Taylor said.ldquoMaggie was on her own, the staff were furloughed. We relied on locals ndash they were fantastic and kept us going in spirits as well as financially. This is Maggiersquos baby and there was no way she would let it go. She would have slept in itshe had to.Nick Green opened Aberfoyle Bike Hire three years ago in a former butcherrsquos shop.He has watched the progression in the recovery of the village during his time there. ldquoItrsquos been getting busier since I moved here, he said. ldquoLast summer was very busy and the main street was in a good condition.His business has been more fortunate than perhaps some others ndash as a bike shop he was allowed to remain open all the time and, as well documented, cycling has enjoyed something of a resurgence during the pandemic.ldquoWe were doing a lot of repairs for locals at the start, he said. ldquoFrom the start of lockdown there was an upsurge in cycling which has been universal across the country.Despite the initial pause in trading in the first few weeks, he believes businesses adapted and those that would have catered for tourists offered services to locals instead.And, far from seeing new businesses struggling to cope with Covid more than established ones, he thinks it could have worked to their advantage.ldquoI donrsquot think Aberfoyle was any harder hit by Covid than where ndash I think the businesses in the Main Street are quite well founded even though they may be in their first years, he said. ldquoIn fact, with businesses being quite new itrsquos been helpful because they are flexible and can adapt more easily.ldquoIn the early stages of lockdown businesses that would have served tourists refocused on the local community.ldquoLocal people definitely made an effort to support businesses and vice versa. Businesses stepped up to help vulnerable people and thatrsquos nice to see. We donated one of our bikes to someone who was volunteering to pick up prescriptions. There was a positive atmosphere.He said there had been ldquoincreasing anxiety when more people started arriving but ldquoyou have to balance that with the reality that Aberfoyle relies on visitors. As more family visitors started arriving when lockdown lted the anti-social behaviour and littering that had plagued the village earlier on had eased, he said.The past five or six weeks have seen something of a revival for Aberfoyle with an influx of English tourists.ldquoThere were definitely more tourists from England than normal, he said. ldquoWe are not getting the normal bus tour traffic which has always been a source of visitors but we have been getting a lot of families from the UK who are having their holidays here. Perhaps the staycation trend will be repeated in future years. Hopefully thatrsquos something we can capitalise on.Trevor Geraghty, chairman of the local Strathard Community Council, said that, in some ways, lockdown had boosted local businesses and the local community.He said people were essentially forced to shop locally much more than they ever had and that certain shops in Aberfoyle ndashincluding the Co-op, pharmacy and the butcher ndash had thrived in the early stages of lockdown.ldquoIn remote areas you typically have workers commuting to bigger cities and they do their shopping on their commute he said. ldquoThe Post Office here became a massive leline and had more to do than they ever had. There was tons of community spirit -ndashIntrepidco-ordinated collections for a charity in Glasgow, for example.He admitted that businesses badly affected where were naturally similarly affected in Aberfoyle but said locals made an effort to support local businesses once lockdown started to ease. ldquoThere were absolutely some businesses that did well and probably better than normal in terms of the local community making up, in some way, for the [tourism] drop in businesses, he added. ldquoAnd with people spending more time in their communities [earlier in lockdown] it opened their eyes as to what is on their doorstep ndash cycles they might never have done, or trails they havenrsquot explored.With a new Co-op to take over the vacant garden centre site on Main Street, the ldquoanchor project signals things are still on the up in Aberfoyle, he said. ldquoItrsquos not easy, but itrsquos not all grim.Local councillor Martin Earl said you could be forgiven for thinking ldquothese past few months would have dealt a blow from which such places would struggle to recover from.The truth was ldquofar from it, he said. ldquoThe community spirit, support for local businesses and the determination to pull on through is what we have seen in spades, he added. ldquoAberfoyle, its people and the businesses it supports is in good shape and is going to get better and better. Responsible visitors are welcome and always will be.Across in Maggiersquos Aberfoyle Kitchen, business is now booming and the shop has opened seven days a week for the past three weeks. ldquoWe are getting a lot of visitors from all over the UK, Mr Taylor said. ldquoLast weekend was the busiest day of the year so far.ldquoItrsquos fantastic for us. We are getting a lot of visitors from Ireland and Wales, as well as Scotland. Itrsquos quite heartening.During the leaner Covid times the business adapted and started stocking high quality Scottish gts to add to their income and Mr Taylor said it was ldquoworking well for us.How long the summer trade will last, however, is something that is worrying everyone. ldquoWe are now looking at surviving this winter and then building on that, he added. ldquoNo-one knows what will happen but I think wersquoll be OK.

title: snp-msp-roseanna-cunningham-stand-next-election
story: Environment Secretary Roseanna Cunningham announced today that she will not be seeking re-election in next yearrsquos parliamentary election.Ms. Cunningham has served in the Scottish Parliament since , having previously represented Perth as an SNP MP.The SNP MSP for Perthshire South  Kinross-shire has previously served under Alex Salmond and Nicola Sturgeonrsquos governments where she currently holds the title of Cabinet Secretary for Environment, Climate Change and Land Reform.:PM Boris Johnson cuts short holiday in Scotland as location is revealedMs.Cunningham wrote in a statement on Twitter:Folks, a bit of an announcement to make. Itrsquos been a tough call, but Irsquove told my Constituency Association that I wonrsquot be standing for Parliament again next year.Formal statement below pic XLgpXlAy"It has been a massive honour to have represented my constituents in both Westminster and the Scottish Parliament for the past  years and to have been able to serve my country as a Cabinet Secretary in the Scottish Government."I have always been hugely grateful to all those who have put their faith in me. In the first instance, the local members of the SNP for selecting me as their candidate and working so hard during and between election campaigns but, above all, the voters of the constituencies I have represented through ious boundary changes for voting for me and the party."In doing so, they made history by making Perth  Kinross the first seat that the SNP would win at a by-election and hold at the subsequent by-election, and they ensured that I became the longest-serving current Scottish parliamentarian."The support of onersquos constituents is not only essential for political success, it is immensely humbling and I am very thankful for it."It has been a great privilege, too, to have been in government since  ndash and in  dferent portfolios ndash first as Environment Minister, then Community Safety Minister, then in Cabinet as Cabinet Secretary for Fair Work, Skills  Training and then back to my original portfolio but this time as Cabinet Secretary for Environment, Climate Change  Land Reform.:SNP womens rights activist blasts Kenny MacAskills Alex Salmond conspiracy comments"After a quarter of a century as an elected politician, and with another election fast approaching, I have had to do some hard thinking. By the time of the next election I will be less than two months away from my th birthday and, further, by the end of that parliamentary term I would be nearly . This year, of all years, has made age a rather more relevant factor than it may otherwise have been."I have, accordingly, taken the very dficult decision to inform my local Constituency Association that I will not be seeking nomination as an SNP candidate for the  Scottish Parliament elections."
